docs.lead_paragraph: Gen. ADONIKAM CRANDLER, late Corresponding Secretary and Acting Agent of the American Institute, died at his residence in this City on Saturday. Gen. CHANDLER was an early friend of American Industry, and cherished a profound interest in the prosperity of the Institution with which he was connected.

docs.lead_paragraph: " Provide against a rainy day," is a sagacious maxim of street, as well as social philosophy. We have had a long spell of dry weather, rather more, perhaps, than our Western farmers desired, and, almost as necessary consequence, have had comparatively clean streets.

docs.lead_paragraph: Through the courtesy of Captain LUCE, we are enabled to give, this morning, additional particulars of the highest interest concerning the wreck of the Arctic. The incidents of the catastrophe, and the details of the position, conduct and measures for safety of the passengers during the last moments of their being upon the ship, which Captain LUCE narrated to our Reporter, will be read with deep and universal interest.

headline.main: IMPORTANT FROM EUROPE.; COMPLETE AND DECISIVE VICTORY OF THE ALLIES DOWNFALL OF SEBASTOPOL. INTERESTING DETAILS OF THE LANDING. Surrender of the Ships, Stores, Forts, Gnns, &c. &c. ARRIVAL OF THE BALTIC. Great Battle Between the Russians and the Allied Armies. Defeat of the Russians---18,000 Killed and Wounded.

docs.lead_paragraph: The American steamer Baltic, Capt. ComSTOCK, reached this port at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, having left Liverpool on the 4th of October, at 9.50 A. M. The Baltic experienced heavy westerly winds throughout the passage, and on the 6th and 11th encountered heavy gales, accompanied by severe squalls from S. S. W. to N. N. W., with heavy seas.

headline.main: THE ARCTIC.; INTERESTING STATEMENT OF MR. GILBERT. Statements of Messrs. Mitchell, Dupasseur and Degnon. THRILLING NARRATIVE OF CAPT. LUCE. Rescue of Capt. Luce and Nine Others by the Bark Cambria.
The Yellow Fever at the South--The Bridge Over the Poe Deo River--Victory of the Know-Nothings

docs.lead_paragraph: The Southern mail, as late as due, has been received, with New-Orleans papers of Monday. At Savannah, for the week ending the 11th inst., there were thirty-three deaths, fifteen of which were from. yellow fever. The Board of Health caution absentees against returning.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Health Officer reports eighty deaths as having occurred in this city during the week ending Oct. 14, from the following diseases: Atrophy, congestion of the brain, convutsions puerperal diabetes, typhoid fever, typhus fever, hetnorrh of the longs hemorrhage of the bowels. inflammation of the stomach, inflammation of the uterius, malformation, mumes, old age. parturition, Premature birth, sprue, unknown--one each.
